text: Hey there! Lots of information out there. Check out the Coursera courses. One that comes to mind that I’ve used is Issac Randansky AdWords course. Also check out Surfside PPC on YouTube. For beautiful design and branding I like to check out the works on Pentagram Design which is an agency in NYC and worldwide that has a plethora of amazing work. Hope this helps.

text: Before accepting a role, I ask a LOT of questions. I ask about team dynamics, how much vacation time everyone HAS to take (vs how much is offered), if someone else on the team was hoping to get the role I've been offered and didn't, what the team and company turnover rate is, what formal leadership growth programs are in place, if I'll be a mentor/receive a mentor, benefits structure for not-so-obvious things (like you could ask about paternity leave or annual $$ for conference attendance), if I have a budget for small bonuses for my team (coffees or Amazon gift cards or if I can give everyone the last Friday of the month off at the end of a project), etc. If these things aren't in place, I ask how difficult it would be for me to implement them within the first 60 days of my employment. It's really easy to read a room based on the answers to all of these questions.

It's really easy to read a room based on the answers to all of these questions.

text:
What you're describing (creating a margin by substantially increasing your prices, allowing you to pay a peer a similar rate to what you've historically commanded) is going from freelancer to agency like that {snaps fingers}.  The problem with that is twofold:
1. Agencies deliver value for their margin that you don't yet have a history of delivering to justify that rate increase.
2. Do you want to own an agency?  (If so, your goal just became to stop writing content and become the managing director of an agency)

elements.text: What you're describing (creating a margin by substantially increasing your prices, allowing you to pay a peer a similar rate to what you've historically commanded) is going from freelancer to agency like that {snaps fingers}.  The problem with that is twofold:
Agencies deliver value for their margin that you don't yet have a history of delivering to justify that rate increase.
Do you want to own an agency?  (If so, your goal just became to stop writing content and become the managing director of an agency)

text: So the thing that I'd ask myself if I were you is whether owning an agency is your goal and, if so, being intentional about creating the situation where you can justify substantially higher rates for a sustained period of time (IOW, not because a client is in a pinch and doesn't know where else to look for the moment)

elements.text: So the thing that I'd ask myself if I were you is whether owning an agency is your goal and, if so, being intentional about creating the situation where you can justify substantially higher rates for a sustained period of time (IOW, not because a client is in a pinch and doesn't know where else to look for the moment)

text:
If that's a lot to think on, understand that there are other ways to monetize a lead without punting it:
• Ask a finder's fee of 10% revenue for the first year from another freelancer
• Keep the relationship, but take 10% off the top from another freelancer
• Create a mutual referral network and have the person you refer the work to owe you future leads
• Tell them you're busy, but you're happy, for a small fee to help them recruit and vet freelancers.
• Tell them you're running a waiting list at the moment, but may free up later, and take the business.

elements.text: If that's a lot to think on, understand that there are other ways to monetize a lead without punting it:
Ask a finder's fee of 10% revenue for the first year from another freelancer
Keep the relationship, but take 10% off the top from another freelancer
Create a mutual referral network and have the person you refer the work to owe you future leads
Tell them you're busy, but you're happy, for a small fee to help them recruit and vet freelancers.
Tell them you're running a waiting list at the moment, but may free up later, and take the business.

text: FWIW, something I'd offer as a general piece of operating business wisdom is never to create a situation where you're earning money only because a client and subcontractor are too polite to cut you out of the middle, or sign a contract to that effect.  People's take on business ethics aside, it's a risky position to be in to have your livelihood depending on two parties not meeting each other.
